newsitem.title: FRANCE: Cargo nears 20pct of Air France turnover.
newsitem.headline: Cargo nears 20pct of Air France turnover.

text.p: Cargo is close to contributing 20 percent of Air France's group turnover and will continue to be a major profit centre in coming years, group chief financial officer Patrice Durand said.

He told Reuters in an interview that cargo was making "significant, positive contributions to the bottom line even in a situation where the company was losing money and now accounts for seven billion francs of group turnover against 29 billion francs from passengers."
In June, Air France reported consolidated turnover of 43.23 billion francs for the financial year 1995-1996 compared to 44.69 billion in the previous year.

He added that Air France was making "a big investment in Roissy to build a very efficient cargo operating base." This entails consolidation of the former Air France and UTA cargo centres into a single, state-of-the-art complex.
Work on the site started in March 1995 and the 411 million franc project, able to handle up to 950,000 tonnes of cargo a year, is due to be completed by October 1998.

Separately Air France's cargo director general Sten Grotenfelt said other investment in cargo would include new dedicated capacity "to serve thinner routes" plus conversion of an existing Boeing 747-200 combi for all freight use in March 1997.
Air France operates six 747-200 combis and six 747-400 as well as 11 dedicated 747 freighters. The 747-200s will be phased out from the beginning of 1997.
Grotenfelt added that he wants three more dedicated freighters for thinner routes over the next three years "by one means or another".
Under review are the Airbus Industrie A300 "which has range problems," the McDonnell Douglas MD-11 "which is a fairly long range aircraft" or maybe the Lockheed L-1011 Tristar," he said.
Recently-announced orders for 10 new Boeing 777-200s and 10 Airbus A340s will provide extra belly capacity, Grotenfelt added. --Air Cargo Newsroom Tel+44 171 542 7706 Fax+44 171 542 5017
